intro: Humboltia elongata, commonly known as the longleaf humboldtia, is a shrub native to South America, particularly found in regions of Brazil and Paraguay. It belongs to the Malvaceae family, which includes hibiscus and cotton plants, and is characterized by its hairy stems and broad, lance-shaped leaves. The plant produces showy, yellow flowers with five petals, often arranged in clusters at the ends of branches. Humboltia elongata is adapted to grow in moist, tropical environments and is often found in humid lowland areas. Its botanical features make it an interesting subject for both ecological studies and ornamental gardening.
